titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of John of Bordeaux or the Second Part of Friar Bacon (1936)

publicationStmt.publisher: John of Bordeaux: or the Second Part of Friar Bacon Oxford University Press 1936 Source text incomplete

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
John of Bordeaux. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1936. Authorial attribution is questionable Date first performed: 1590-1594.
Text from LION checked against the Malone Soc edition of the ms. ed. William Lindsay Renwick, Oxford, 1936 (in Auchmuty)

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Emperor Fredrick John of Bordeaux Jacques Vandermast Friar Bacon Rossalin Ferdinand Nobleman Lord Rossacler Amurath; Turkish Emperor Asteroth; a Devil Perce; Bacons man Vandermasts wife Sellimus neighbours wife neighbour j scoller ij scoller Servio old woman offycer Bashaws souldier
Cunstable devell Corebus; shepherd Damon; shepherd nimph

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter Emperor, Iohn of Burdiox his wif Rossalin his son Rossacler Vandermast frier Bacon with attendantes

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: Sir Iohn of Burdiox haughty in thy thought, martial and and full of warlike excellence, well hast thou kept Revena against the Turk though Ameroth beleaguered y it with men for which I praise thee much and prize thee dear, I tell thee Iohn thou art loved of ffredricke, for proof thy son shall wait upon my Cup. thy daughter and fair Rossalin thy wife shall with the Empress feast it in the Court and thou thyself even Iohn of Burdiox shall rescue Revena and be lord thereof and for thou wants a fresh supply of men thou shalt have thirty thousand strong to aid thee against the assaults of Amerothe

sp.speaker: Iohn
sp.p: worthy supporter of the Germans' state Huan of Burdiox was mine Ancestor and at his honours do I aim my thoughts I prize my prince above my private self and Country's Credit more than loss of blood, amongst all the favours from your Excellence my son's preferment I account as chief for fathers glory in their sons adore and that the Empress deigns my wife's consort, Sir Iohn is soldier to her mightiness void in her quarrel for to break his Lance and for Ravenna's guest Burdox will be a faithful subject unto fredricke

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.p: I know it Iohn, Bacon why art not blithe, wert thou at oxford in thy house of brasenose, more hearty welcome could not Bakon have than fredrick in heart affords to him it is thy disgrace I tell thee vandermast if Bakon welcome fits not his content, scholars should link in sympathy of Love what Germany Affords in honer or in wealth. is thine to grace friar Bakon with and hosburge and their schools may hold them proud that English Bakon lives within their sell

sp.speaker: Vander
sp.p: Bakon is welcome unto vandermast and hosburge holds the man in great accompt, though I have little case to wish him well for well I wot when I in England was. your grace can tell he set me on a stead Jade that posted me in haste from Albion a vengeance and a whirlwind brought me home wisdom

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: I know it well that envy hath her spleen, and envy lives amongst the greatest clerks for all this check be merry ma thou art welcome to the German emperor that glories in the presence of thyself

sp.speaker: Bakon
sp.p: I thank your grace Bakon left not his English schools to gain abroad wealth or promotion desire of deeper skill mad me cost unto the German clime Bacon is old and age cannot be blithe for many years must meditate on sin yet I confess y highness Courtesy to far more than my deserts can c bu t as for hosborge and for vandermast as thee account of Bacon so do I of them

sp.speaker: iox
sp.p: when I was young and sought the English strand to show I was a soldier in that cost, as youth desires to show their chivalry, coming to Oxford there to see there schools Bacon that wished to do all strangers good gave me great welcome with a bound of cheer to gratulate the man and honer him let him my lord be guest at Burdiox house my mansion shall be harbour for the friar and I will case fair Rossalin my wife to love the man as she doth like of me

sp.speaker: ossalin
sp.l: he shall not want a welcome then my Lord

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: Sir Iohn I take it kindly at your hand, I would your English welcome had been more but friar's diet must not revel it two dishes makes a scholar's cheer exceed but for I have long desired to see the turk to witness with mine eyes what I have read I will to Revena marching with your troupes and see a while the accidents of war then will I return again to ffredricke

sp.speaker: Burdiox Bourdeux
sp.p: Bacon content thou shalt have soldiers fair but welcome as it were unto a king

sp.speaker: Empro
sp.p: thanks Burdiox thou honourest me in this in that thou likest of Bacon meanwhile until our soldiers tropes them hence let us in and blithely teach the English friar our Rhenish wine can make a mere heart

body.stage: Enter Rossaclere fferdynand the Emperors son and his toe frend ij noble men

sp.speaker: ble
sp.p: what Cheer my lord what over clad in dumps the prince that swelleth in his one content and hath the empire tied to his will and sit as one that sorrowed for want come ferdenand let us to the Court and in a stoup of wine bury these cars that makes thy honer sad a tipsy head is full of pleasant toys and there is no better salve for discontent, than take a potion brewed from the press

sp.speaker: erdenand
sp.p: what fire on fire it is contrary to kind, a heating grape slakes not a thirsty mind o well said Ovid in his wanton wright venus it vinis egnes et egna fuet

sp.speaker: l rd
sp.p: my lord let us frolic it amongst the dames a woman's face is enemy to car and beauty slaketh every solemn dump

sp.speaker: enand
sp.p: but if that beauty once hath bread thy bane what medicine then by physic may be taken

sp.speaker: d
sp.p: why woe my lord and wine my lord by wealth princes have quoine and that is the suriest Clawes had phebus followed Jupiter in love and crossed fair Daphnie with a golden shower, Daphnie as Dania had been made a mother

sp.speaker: denand
sp.p: Daphni it were she but as coy as she time would make hop believe it once might be but phebus love was never half so loath to grace the son god with a wanton eye as is this saint that maketh me so sad

sp.l: whi hat is h my Lord

sp.speaker: ferde
sp.p: as friend in life so be my friends in love it is fair Rossa ross the fair too fair because her fairness is so chaste, I Court she coy I tell my griefful plaints but all my Love is buried up in loss Counsel how to obtain a Dame so fair

sp.speaker: j lord
sp.p: why faint not ferdenand though soiled at first women's disdains are ended in desires, the harder goat the sweeter in the taste try art my Lord go unto vandermast

sp.speaker: ferdena
sp.p: thou Vandermast and none but Vandermast may ease the sorrows of my grieved soul to him I will go and if he may recure or ease by art what love hath wrought in me I will make him equal with myself in gree, but if that herbs or spells may cure the mind I marvel why impatient phebus cried ha me he quod nullus amor est medecabeles herbs yet will I try the art of vandermast

body.stage: Enter Ambrothe the turke with Basshaws

sp.speaker: turke
sp.p: it grieves me Bashaws and bold Janissaries that Amewrothe whose worth hath won the world should be rejected at Revena back a little town begirt with slender walls yet scorning all the assaults of Amewroth

sp.speaker: Bassha
sp.p: my lord it is not the Countermurs that counterchecks valour of your highness chivalry but Iohn of Burdiox that brave martial lord he is the Key that keeps the City walls and in his valour doth their safety rest

sp.speaker: turk
sp.p: like thetis darling trotting on his steed chasing the men of illion from their tents so Iohn of Burdiox fares him in the field
had I so brave a Bashaw in my camp all Europe's conquest should not bow the man, what noise is this stand on your guard
sp.l: my friends

sp.speaker: BasshaB
sp.p: bring away those Christians this Lordly churl that stand upon his state as if he might compare with any King

body.stage: Enter Bacon and perce his man led in by turkes

sp.speaker: emperor
sp.l: Bashaw what news

sp.speaker: BasshawB
sp.p: sallying about these neighbour bordering groves we found these Christians setted in a thicket this poring on a book wherein was drawn forms and Characters that seem most strange this other whom we hold to be his man sat Just direct him with an instrument by all conjectures seeming magical as if he meant by art to draw the perfect Cityu of your we seeing them laid hold upon the men they scorning wh we ether did or dare as men that little weighed our force or veiling little of the threats of death

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: hark ye sir pray what might he seem to be you have talked unto all this while

sp.speaker: souldier B
sp.l: marry sirrah it is Amerothe emperor of the turks

sp.speaker: perce
sp.l: alas good Gentleman I am heartily sorry for him I promise

sp.speaker: sould
sp.l: why so

sp.speaker: (perce)
sp.p: he seems to be troubled with the headache he has such a vengeable many of clouts he bought the pat on him ow what art thou

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.l: a Christian born my calling is a friar

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.p: strange are thy looks and uncouth thy nature never have I seen such garments in camp yet many Christian prisoners have we taken what canst thou do or what is thy degree

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: I can march through the thickest of thy tropes and daunt thy Janissaries with a frown, making thy Bashaws bow when I Command, my angry looks can make proud Amewroth shroud him within the compass of his guard, and at my lust great Constanttinople shall vanish as did illion into flames; Turk I can bridle all thy power by art thus for my skill and now for my degree I am English Bacon, what sayst thou to me

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: oft have I seen the portraiture of pride shadowed within a Christian's haughty looks for most of them are men of high Conceit but such a proud resolving groom as this pricked up with such disdaining insolence, never came before the face of Amewroth an english man well mayst though be a devil such stern import hangs in thy frowning brow but now thou hast met with one will be thy match and chasted all thy follies with a frown step callibassha and with thy sword reach me that proud presuming Christian's head then let him make compare with Amewrothe what is the matter

sp.speaker: perce
sp.l: his dudgeon haft is angry and his sword begins to clatter

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.l: tell me villain wherefore camest thou

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: I for to gratulate my princely friend came wandering Amewroth unto thy camp th to have thy crown thy robe and scimitar, which I will have maugre thy proudest guard ere thou and I depart ourselves from hence grudge not but yield them me without delay, for English Bacon will not have a nay

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: blasphemous Christian what my royal crown framed at the cost of warlike ottoman that first was supreme of the mighty Turks my curious robe and my scimitar my I exchange them for the western world and have the land that Limits from the alps unto the farthest setting of the sun I would not leave my robe nor yet my crown, my scimitar see Christian how it shines full well thou likest it now it shall be thine, hold him
I will butcher up the slave despite of all the quilts of art

body.stage: Enter Selimus a soulder persuing him

sp.speaker: imus
sp.l: help help o help

sp.speaker: ke
sp.p: the voice doth show like little Selimus ha it is he stay soldier stay thy hands stay and take ransom what what thyself wilt ask

sp.speaker: Selim
sp.p: forbear the blow see where my father sits and proffers ransom for his only son

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.l: forbear him yet

sp.speaker: Selimus
sp.p: why sites my father as a man secure Carls to help his only Selimus or else to fly for why the enemy hath sallied out Revena with his force spoiled thy camp and left not one alive only myself did save my life by flight, but hot pursuit this soldier gave me chase so at thy feet thy son must either die or else have life by thy persuading words

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: how his Laments doth wring me at the heart to see the boy the babe of m delights ready to die and I can lend no aid I sit enchained with sprig I cannot stir I cannot move lording stir you not

sp.speaker: noble
sp.p: the devil I think or else some worser hath so enchanted us we cannot move

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.l: strike

sp.speaker: (Selimus)
sp.p: ha father now the baleful blade is up help now or never father shall I die

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: ha might I die with thee then were I well

sp.speaker: Sellimus
sp.p: remember how my mother Loves me well, think how she will shed her brinish tires for me when Selimus her only son must d for her sake Gentle father save my Lief give all thy kingdom for thy only son

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.l: strike

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: hold Bacon take thou my Crown my robe my scimitar and what else I have only entreat to save my Little entreat nay charge for thy command is done

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: deliver them unto my man and Bacon swears to thee thy son shall have no prejudice at all

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: master shall I give him my cape my gown and my sword and then he cannot say that we are beholding to him for exchange is no robbery I remember once at oxford in a Comedy your worship put me to play the part of a chimney sweeper and after to clear the stage you carried me away in a cloak bag now this is Like to prove a tragedy I put on the Turk's robes and make an exeunt in his best apparel

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.p: Bacon now thou hast all deliver thou me my son

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: Astrough go shroud thyself and him straight in the deep

sp.speaker: Seli
sp.l: ha help help

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.l: ah Bacon what hast thou done

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: taken thy robes and sent thy son to hell thus English Bacon bids the Turk farewell farewell good man Turk I believe you will love hogs' flesh the worse this seven year ye have been so hardly handled by Bacon

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: now can I steer now that the slave is gone my limes have wonted liberty again

sp.speaker: j lord
sp.p: and so have mine my Lord but whether shall we fly this Cursed Bacon will haunt us at the heels

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: how can I live now selimus that my son is dead now selemus my only son is slain

sp.speaker: lordB
sp.l: my lord see where selimus comes

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.l: Selimus ha no it is his ghost

sp.speaker: Selim
sp.p: all hail unto the mighty Amewrath thy lords are all in counsel of he bought some present business to be done and sent me to entreat your majesty you would make short repair unto your royal tents

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.l: Selimus my son what dost thou live my boy

sp.speaker: Seli
sp.p: what makes my father make a question so I was not sick but frolic as you see then who dares offer selemus any wrong

sp.speaker: Turke
sp.p: why say my son wert thou not here even now suppliant at a solder's feet for life saying our Bashaws all were put to sword

sp.speaker: Seli
sp.p: who I my lord my tutor and myself have all this day been plodding at our books until the Lords entreated me to come

sp.speaker: Turk
sp.l: how say to this my Lords

sp.speaker: lordB
sp.p: Bacon by magic spells raised up some sprite in likeness of your son and by that means and by that means hath got your robes away for he that could enchant us to stand still can do as great a miracle as this

sp.speaker: urk
sp.p: now that I have my selemus again this tragic stir is turned all to Joy welcome my boy and to my robes adieu h let friar Bacon wear them for my sake it is well may he boast he is cozen to the turk so fine he fetch me off with his deceit yet is the friar a man in all his word my selimvs is safe and so he void but if I live I will down to hosborge plains and fetch from fredrick my Crown my sword and scimitar or die
sp.l: come Bashaws let go give assault

sp.speaker: rydynand
sp.p: be Courteous rose as thou art heavenly fair fair rossalin take ruth of my distress passions in love passages to death and sorer pricks the sting of deep affect then any pain that can torment the heart see I thy face my thoughts are full of fire, but as the oil doth make the fire more great so tires quench not but doth increase the heat

sp.speaker: ssalin
sp.p: what sugared words drops from a lovers tongue how painted is the speech that love affords ah could my lord discourse of vertue so; and talk as well of chastity as Lust it were far more better for his princely state; these foolish passions little please my mind it fits not married wives to list to love a willing ear
bewrays a wanton heart and therefore pardon for I must depart

sp.speaker: fferd
sp.p: absence is death upon so quoy disdain stay Rossalin be pliant to my plaint thou canst not have a truer love than I

sp.speaker: ossalin
sp.l: nor none so true as Iohn of Burdiox is

sp.speaker: fferd
sp.p: hold take this treasure thresher of my heart, a sacrifice of for my submissive thought which humbly bows before thy beauteous feet

sp.speaker: Rossalin
sp.p: tempt me not wanton lord with strains of sin for no corruption shall enchant my mind, rather in sorrow let me beg my bread and work in sorrow to maintain my state before be false I false my faith unto my lord

sp.speaker: fernand
sp.p: my countenance shall overbear that blame

sp.speaker: rossalin
sp.p: a wretched choler for a sinful life where honour's veil doth shadow lawless lust, my lord the faith of Iohn of Burdiox his service in your royal father's wars his wounds his blood in Country's quarrel shed deserve the this requital at your hands that thus you seek to spoil his married wife for sham forbear for if you thus persevere

sp.l: the emperor shall know how much you wrong me

sp.speaker: fferd
sp.l: wilt thou be gone

sp.speaker: Rossalin
sp.p: peace siren temp me no more unless you will the world shall hear your shame

and wilt thou part thou part thou sun of my delight from whence the lower lights of glorion derive their beauties and do draw their clear then in some and dark and obs obscure cell of care where melancholy dwells or sorrow haunts I will go sigh my sacrifice of to Love

sp.speaker: vander
sp.p: how now my lord what is this woman won I heard fair rossalin and you were here that made me hie me for to hear what news

sp.speaker: ferd
sp.p: ha vandermast Daphnie was never so q coy nor Roman lucres half so chaste in thoughts plead I she hath excuses for my suit so chaste so honest and so resolute as that the gall and pinch me to the heart

sp.speaker: nder
sp.p: Why then you are no conning wooer for women will be won

sp.speaker: rd
sp.p: then all but she for do I proffer love she swears it is not love but lust, present I gold she scorns the plea of pelf she scorns the plea of pelf and Jewels why she hold scorns them all as trash and but her husband all unfit for her were the greatest monarch of the world thus she disdains and yet in her mislike, she harbours matchless chastity and love, that honer wills me not to work her wrong, but spite of honer and all royal thoughts Love says I must and then by heaven I will, then task the vander mast unto thy books, help by thy art let magic be A means to get me grace of Lovely Rossaline and I will make thee partner of my wealth

sp.speaker: vander
sp.p: ha ferdenand the mind is such a thing as is beyond the reach of any art she that is chaste cannot be won with charms

sp.speaker: fferd
sp.l: then all my love is buried up in loss

sp.speaker: vand
sp.p: not so my Lord we will have another plot, where wealth wines not a woman unto love there rather is abundance in or contempt, but let that damsel be oppressed with want touch her with ned and that will make her shrink were Rossalin deprived of her state and poor as now she over flows with wealth, girt with distress she would be soon reclaimed, and glad for gold to yield to any love

sp.speaker: ffer
sp.l: but how shall this be brought to pass

sp.speaker: vand
sp.p: why thus I will raise a spirit in some turkish shape like to a messenger from Ameroth, and he shall bring a letter from his Lord wherein sir Iohn of Burdiox private hand shall be set down with lively counterfeit how that for gold he will resign the town and all the treasure to the mighty Turk when thus your father is incensed with ire; buzzes in his ears suspicion of the man and leave not harping on that hateful string, tell he be driven as exile from the land and wife and Children turned out of doors, when thus she sees her that fortune gins to frown then will she change her thoughts and smile in time

sp.speaker: fferd
sp.l: but if this will not do how then

sp.speaker: vand
sp.p: then thus my Lord when Lovely in her bead the lady lies secure within the harbour of her thoughts, I will bring her in her night gown unto you, if then you win not your worthy loss

sp.speaker: Rossa
sp.p: so pleasing is the promise of thy speech that I am eased of half my deep despair, for proof I men to quit thy travels well thou shalt receive these Jewels rossalin refused and Iaquies come this day and dine with me

sp.speaker: j scoller
sp.p: Come hither perce tell us how long hast thou served friar Bacon

sp.speaker: perce
sp.l: marry ever since friar Bacon hath been my master

sp.speaker: ij scolle
sp.l: and I prithee perce what hath he taught thee

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: marry he hath taught me three principles and these they be imprimis that a good fellow's purse is like a pot of ale for every man will have a flirt at it until it be empty

sp.speaker: j scoller
sp.l: what is the next

sp.p: the second he that hath neither money nor credit may make all the week fasting days by authority

sp.speaker: sco
sp.l: excellent perce what is the last

sp.speaker: erce
sp.p: lastly he that means to Live in this world must have his tongue made of a painter's apron spotted of all colours he face brace cog lie and dissemble or else if he live never so honestly he shall di a stark beggar

sp.speaker: ij scoll
sp.p: but tell me perce he being so learned a man hath he taught thee any latin

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: Aye marry has he and you shall hear some, yf yf nesuter vltra crepedam

sp.speaker: j scoller
sp.l: what is the meaning

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: this if a cobbler prove a constable have not your shows mended of him that year

sp.speaker: scoler
sp.l: your reason perce

sp.speaker: Perce
sp.p: marry if not for your king your shoes well you should hang the knave upon his shoulders his offence would reward you with a payer of stocks for your Labour

sp.speaker: ij scolle
sp.p: but perce hath he taught to distinguish a noun adjective from a none substantive

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: Aye that he hath and this it is a noun adjective is a barrel of strong beer for if it be epse he in barrel la or titled by the name of hufcape it will make a man not able to stand by himself but throw him for a noun adjective quit under the table

sp.speaker: j scoller
sp.l: well said perce now what is a noun substantive

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: ho my masters war of a noun substantive it is a Dangerous point of learning for I knew a wench in oxford dell so long with a noun substantive that first she cried out of a chopping boy and after was whipped up and down the town for Lechery

sp.speaker: ii scoller
sp.p: but perce hath he taught thee no point of magic we are so dry with talking we know not what to do now if thou couldst conger us to bottle of awl hither we would honour forever

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: why what dry slaves are you I am sure I have walked my Leather in my mouth as much as you and yet I am not a dry come hither let us reason with you in matter of doctrine what is your profession philosophy and here is plato

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: philosophy and here is plato this is plato, and what is your profession

sp.speaker: scoller
sp.l: Logic and here is Aristotle

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: logic and and here is plato Aristotle well here I put in plato and here I put in aristotle now you would think strange to turn your two books into two bottles of ale now if I be friar Bacons or no Judge you here is plato for you and here is aristotle for you now drink to me and I will be moderator in this controversy, well said plato ho well done aristotle thou goest to the ground of the matter nayles your dry scholars indeed drink of plato and aristotle ast

sp.speaker: j scoller
sp.p: gramercy good a thousand times come prithee give us our boo our hour is come we cannot stay another time we will do as much f o

sp.speaker: Perce
sp.p: nay nay your books are turned into two bottles of awl for as it was a point of magic to torn your books into two bottles of ale so it is a point of philosophy you should pay for your ale before you have your books

sp.speaker: ij scol
sp.p: why pearce our books cost us a crown

sp.speaker: perce
sp.p: all the better for me for my bottles cost me but three pence now if by magic you can get your books again I will say vandermast hath taught you somewhat if not fools I found you and foul I leave ye

body.stage: Enter emperor and his son frier Bacon Iohn of Burdox son yong rossaclere and vandermast

sp.speaker: emperor
sp.p: How likest me Bacon in my turkish robes, how sits this diadem upon my head how hangs my scimitar what grace the me adorn the my imperial state or no

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: fredrick looks like the haughty god of war when clad in pomp of all his royalty he shows the triumphs of his thoughts in heaven

sp.speaker: emperor
sp.p: now frolic friar I prithee tell me why great Ameroth did pries these things so dear

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: for that the forging of that diadem it was done by ottoman from whose decent the turkish princes draw their pedigree as sacred from the head of ottoman the monument of all their royalties depended on the wearing of that crown as sacred from the head of Ottoman

p.del: art cannot do so great a thing my lord

sp.speaker: emperor
sp.p: ha Bacon had thy glass been whole which thou didst break at Oxford in a spleen I might in that have clearly seen my wish for thou art master of all sciences

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: my lord although though my glass be broke was Bacons cunning tied within a glass no please it mighty fredricke to see the warlike stratagems before revena walls I show you in a dream what is there performed as lively as yourself were present there

sp.speaker: emper
sp.p: spoke like a man of art do me that good but sought how shall I fall into a dream having no mind at all to sleep e

sp.speaker: Bacon
sp.p: for that let me alone only sit still while vandermast your son and I attend your grace)

now morpheous raise thee from thy sable den shake of thy robes of love take thee to arms wash all thy weeds in baleful acoran to show the end of stratagems and blood and eiselon thou thou mighty god of dramas great eiselon that figurest forth in sleep visions and shows of mighty stratagems I illeg.] charge thee show to sleeping fredrick the tropes and Coronet s of turkey's horse show him the battles of great Ameroth and phobeter in thy warlike front bring Iohn of Burdiox and his soldiers forth show him the Combat and the doubtful victory Join you in on morphebus phobeter and eisalon et fyet spectator omniam fredricke

body.stage: Exent Bacon to bring in the showes as you knowe

sp.p: bass villain why retirest thou
e what says your highness

sp.speaker: peror
sp.p: ha son my spirit was not here but at revenna in the battle was my soul but where is Bacon

sp.speaker: ander
sp.l: he is gone my Lord

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: ha vander mast as in my sleep I lay I saw great Ameroth in royalty marching with many thousand Janissaries ready to give assault unto the town but Iohn of Burdiox breaking of their sake fearful to fight within a guarded wall, set op the gates turks and made a sally forth, and set upon the turks with such resolve that at the first the pagans fled the field, but with a squadron of approved men the Bashaws enter lined their wearied slaves and gave a hotter charge upon sir Iohn so that the knight was forced to retire for very grief to see Lord Burdiox fly I star up and waking from my dramas cried out bass villain why retirest thou

sp.speaker: ferdenand
sp.p: knew your highness but so much as I you would say it were treason and not cowardice that made the traitor Burdiox to retire

sp.speaker: emperor
sp.l: take heed my son Sir Iohn was ever true

sp.speaker: ferdenan
sp.l: then see my Lord the tenor of his hand

sp.speaker: empero
sp.p: and can such treason harbour in his breast hath Burdiox lived these many winters true and now prove face unto his sovereign who brought these Letters ferdenand

sp.speaker: fer
sp.p: the son of Ameroth did send it me to show how false we Christian's are i'faith it was brought me by a warlike Insure for proof my Lord here is the man himself but little privy to what news he brought

sp.speaker: empe

sp.p: though nobly born come children learn to beg weep when you crave my boys your case is good, bread must be had though it be bought with tear and though you beg it is in my behalf to guard my honer little ones you b eg di we in want yet honoured shall we die who gives one penny to these pensive one penny to relive a matrons want, ha charity thou now art weighed will none give ear come Children walk along one penny master for to buy one penny master for my babes and me ha virtue thou are scorned in misery

sp.speaker: Rossacler

sp.speaker: Rossacle

yet since thy Courtesy commands me speak
I will tell thee all and who my husband was
Sir Iohn of Burdiox was my wedded lord
these are his babes and I his hapless wife, alas why weep you sir

sp.speaker: Rossacler

I for my mother weep she was so like to you
sp.p: but for your children I hold them so dear that I must kiss them for thee touch me never but hark methinks some Gentle is hard at hand I leave you mistress unto your alms and walk away and what I get I will bring you every day

sp.speaker: ossalin

sp.speaker: Rossalin

sp.speaker: sa
sp.p: haste ye my Children need must make us hie I see a Gentleman is passing by better for me to beg a modest wife than bear the scandal of immodest life one penny master to help a lady in distress, with these her children comfortless one penny master I beg not as some beggars would to heap up store if that I could, but as a honest matron should one penny master to sucker those that live in want, our minds are good our goods are scant one penny master though ned assails my love and heavenly saint the graces sits upon her Lovely brow appointing her to keep the only power which nature left to dec herself with all in one penny master we were not born to beg our bread though now we bow and bend to need, good stand me now in stead and help me Gentle master

sp.speaker: d

sp.speaker: ossalin
sp.p: my time and car hath made me quite forget you
why Gentle nymph I was thy friend that sough thy Love with luckless speed, now grant me love and I will end thy heavy harms and help at need

sp.speaker: Rossalin
sp.p: what is it you I gave you your answer long before and yet in suit are you so sore, although I beg from door to door I will never ask you penny more and so farewell good master E

sp.speaker: ferden
sp.p: what then shall hate procure my further harms and bind me captive to a woman's looks exchange thy former love to deadly hat and since she seeks to robe me of my life nothing shall quench my nier but cruel death

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.p: ha servio whether the grief of this unhappy news or strange disease by some infectious air hath crept into my bones I cannot tell but I am passing ill, but say servio was not the town strongly manned or wert thou fearful and despaired of help so good my lord how fell the matter out

sp.speaker: Servio
sp.p: After sir Iohn of Burdiox was exiled the turks impatient of a long delay to see so small a town hold out his force thee drew their troops more nearer to the walls, there had you seen how bold the Bashaws were, how hardly the Janissaries fought how royally great Ameroth himself, performed thee you highness would have said that phileps son, armed with argentin had been come to make a second sack to babylon, I will not say what service I did there let others tell the acts that I performed but sure the Germans stood upon the walls as hardy as the men of Illion that guarded troy from fury of the greeks, but fortune or declining fat of ware favoured the part of mighty Ameroth frowned so upon us that we all were foiled the City sacked and I taken prisoner with them that scaped the fury of the sword

sp.speaker: emp

sp.l: My Rosaline condemned for Burdeaux cause
proud yong fferdinand the foe unto her life
Courage assume unto thee, triple force
And in the justice of her innocence
attempt to free her from deaths violence
But Iohn thou art an exile, and descried
the law lays hold on thee relieves not her:
But a disguise shall mask me from their hate
to free my Rosaline I will tempt my fate
But Burdeaux thou art poor, and poverty
can get no cloak, no covert, no disguise
great hearts in want may purpose not effect
wired with grief and over worn with care
to think upon the wrongs I do sustain
hapless in birth model of misery
to whom shall I make known my griefful smart
my father banished from his native home
my mother wrongfully condemned to die
and I their son disgraced and forlorn
but Coward boy to arms put armour on
and shield thy mother from approaching death
although the foe be mighty yet thy quarrel is good
then for her sake venture thy dearest blood
but stay what aged man lies here
wetting his reverent chokes with grief's true tears true grief's tires
hold aged man take this supply from me
I hope thy prayers in fury of the fight
will do me good to gain my mother right
